questions.question: According to the literature review on the evolution of thyroid diagnostics (L1), what was the primary clinical tool used to assess thyroid function prior to the development of the radioimmunoassay (RIA) in the 1970s?
options: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) testing
Serum TSH measurement
Free T3/Free T4 ratios
Thyroid Ultrasound
questions.explanation: Before the 1970s and the advent of TSH testing, clinicians relied on the Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) and the Achilles tendon reflex test to diagnose thyroid dysfunction.

questions.question: Research on HPT axis dysregulation (L2) indicates that chronic elevation of cortisol has what specific effect on thyroid hormone metabolism?
options: It increases the sensitivity of the TSH receptor
It inhibits the 5'-deiodinase enzyme, reducing T4 to T3 conversion
It stimulates the production of Thyroid Binding Globulin (TBG)
It accelerates the clearance of Reverse T3 (rT3)
questions.explanation: Clinical evidence shows that high cortisol levels suppress TSH secretion and inhibit the 5'-deiodinase enzyme, which is responsible for converting T4 into the active T3 hormone.

questions.question: In the context of the Gut-Thyroid-Immune Axis (L3), what does the 'Molecular Mimicry' theory suggest regarding Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis?
options: Thyroid hormones mimic the structure of insulin
Iodine molecules mimic the structure of selenium
Immune cells mistake thyroid proteins for foreign pathogens like Yersinia enterocolitica
The gut lining mimics the structure of the blood-brain barrier
questions.explanation: Molecular mimicry occurs when the immune system reacts to foreign proteins (like those from certain gut bacteria or gluten) that have a similar sequence to thyroid tissue, leading to an autoimmune attack on the thyroid.

questions.question: A 2019 study by Abbott et al. (L4) investigated the efficacy of the Autoimmune Protocol (AIP) diet in women with Hashimoto's. What was a primary finding of this research?
options: A 90% reduction in TSH levels within 4 weeks
Complete reversal of thyroid tissue scarring
Significant improvement in Quality of Life (QoL) and reduction in C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
No clinical benefit was observed compared to a standard diet
questions.explanation: The study found that while thyroid hormones (TSH/T4) didn't change significantly, participants experienced significant improvements in quality of life and a reduction in systemic inflammation markers like CRP.

questions.question: Meta-analyses regarding Selenium supplementation (L5) suggest that a daily dose of 200mcg of selenomethionine is most effective at reducing which marker?
options: Total T4
Thyroid Peroxidase (TPO) antibodies
Thyroid Binding Globulin (TBG)
Reverse T3
questions.explanation: Multiple meta-analyses have shown that 200mcg of Selenium can reduce TPO antibody titers by 30-50% over a 3-6 month period in patients with autoimmune thyroiditis.

questions.question: L6 discusses Mitochondrial Bioenergetics. Through which mechanism does T3 primarily stimulate mitochondrial biogenesis?
options: By decreasing the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
By activating the coactivator PGC-1α
By inhibiting the Krebs cycle
By reducing the number of mitochondria in the cell
questions.explanation: T3 exerts a powerful influence on metabolism by upregulating PGC-1α, the master regulator of mitochondrial biogenesis, thereby increasing the cell's capacity for ATP production.

questions.question: According to environmental toxicology research (L7), why are Fluoride and Bromide considered 'thyroid disruptors'?
options: They stimulate the overproduction of TSH
They increase the half-life of T4 in the bloodstream
They competitively inhibit iodine uptake via the Sodium-Iodide Symporter (NIS)
They convert T3 into an inactive halogenated byproduct
questions.explanation: Because they are in the same halogen group as Iodine, Fluoride and Bromide can compete for the same receptors (NIS) in the thyroid gland, effectively blocking iodine from entering the gland.

questions.question: The DIO2 polymorphism (rs225014) discussed in Lesson 8 (Genomics) is clinically significant because it is associated with:
options: Excessive iodine absorption in the gut
Impaired T4 to T3 conversion at the intracellular level
Hyperthyroidism in early childhood
Resistance to all forms of thyroid medication
questions.explanation: The DIO2 SNP can result in reduced efficiency of the Type 2 deiodinase enzyme, leading to lower intracellular T3 levels even when serum TSH and T4 levels appear normal.

questions.question: The 'Wolff-Chaikoff Effect,' documented in thyroid research, refers to which phenomenon?
options: The increase in T3 production during exercise
The permanent destruction of the thyroid by radioactive iodine
A transient reduction in thyroid hormone synthesis following high iodine intake
The hereditary nature of Graves' disease
questions.explanation: The Wolff-Chaikoff effect is an autoregulatory phenomenon where a large amount of ingested iodine acutely inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis to prevent hyperthyroidism.

questions.question: Based on the evidence presented in Module 19, which of the following best describes the 'Precision Medicine' approach to thyroid health?
options: Treating all patients based on the standard TSH reference range only
Using high-dose iodine for every patient with fatigue
Integrating genomics, gut microbiome data, and environmental exposures to tailor interventions
Relying exclusively on synthetic T4 (Levothyroxine) as the gold standard
questions.explanation: Precision medicine moves beyond 'one-size-fits-all' by using specific data points—such as SNPs (DIO2), gut health markers, and toxic load—to create individualized protocols for thyroid optimization.
